title: National Register of Historic Places listings in Wilcox County, Alabama
data: State Route 89 32°01′54″N 87°04′06″W / 32.03167°N 87.0684°W / 32.03167 ; -87.0684 ( Ackerville Baptist Church of Christ )
Northern side of State Route 28 , 3.2 mi ( 5.1 km ) north of its junction with State Route 10 32°02′44″N 87°20′07″W / 32.04567°N 87.33521°W / 32.04567 ; -87.33521 ( William King Beck House )
Plantation along the Alabama River near Camden . The main house was built in 1845 for William King Beck , nephew of William R. King . King was the 13th Vice President of the United States
State Route 28 and County Road 22 32°03′14″N 87°21′00″W / 32.05385°N 87.3499°W / 32.05385 ; -87.3499 ( Tristram Bethea House )
Federal style plantation house , built in 1842 for Tristram Bethea . It was the first brick house in the county
East of State Route 41 , 5.5 mi ( 8.9 km ) southwest of Camden 31°54′07″N 87°21′39″W / 31.90188°N 87.36089°W / 31.90188 ; -87.36089 ( Dry Forks Plantation )
Federal style plantation house , built from 1832 to 1834 for James Asbury Tait by skilled slave artisans
Roughly along Old Snow Hill Rd. , County Road 59 , Burson Rd. , and State Route 21 32°00′11″N 86°58′02″W / 32.003056°N 86.967222°W / 32.003056 ; -86.967222 ( Furman Historic District )
Historic district that encompasses most of the community and includes a wide variety of 19th century buildings
Greek Revival style plantation house , built for Joseph Richard Hawthorne in 1854
Greek Revival plantation house , built for John Robert McDowell in 1855
Prehistoric Native American archaeological site with evidence of human occupation from 9000 BC to 1800 AD . Best known for its Burial Urn culture artifacts
Area around the junction of State Routes 10 and 21 31°55′19″N 87°05′01″W / 31.92188°N 87.08368°W / 31.92188 ; -87.08368 ( Oak Hill Historic District )
Historic district containing architectural styles ranging from the various mid-19th century revivals to the Victorian

Roughly along Old Depot , County Roads 59 , 7 , and 61 , Broad St. , Banana St. , State Route 10 , and Adams Dr. 31°52′14″N 86°59′22″W / 31.870556°N 86.989444°W / 31.870556 ; -86.989444 ( Pine Apple Historic District )
Historic district containing architectural styles ranging from the Craftsman to the Colonial Revival
¼ mile southeast of the junction of State Route 28 and McCall Rd . 32°08′30″N 87°25′40″W / 32.14156°N 87.42782°W / 32.14156 ; -87.42782 ( Prairie Mission )
Mission school for African Americans that was founded by the Freedman 's Board of the United Presbyterian Church of North America in 1885
Snow Hill Normal and Industrial Institute
Northern side of County Road 26 , northwest of Snow Hill 32°01′14″N 87°01′59″W / 32.02064°N 87.03298°W / 32.02064 ; -87.03298 ( Snow Hill Normal and Industrial Institute )

African American school founded in 1893 by Dr. William J. Edwards , a graduate of Tuskegee University . It grew over time until , at its height , it included a campus of 27 buildings , a staff of 35 , and over 400 students
Plantation house built for Robert Tait in 1855 . It features a one-story Carolina porch and elaborate interior plasterwork
Irregular pattern along Broad St. 31°59′28″N 87°17′21″W / 31.99123°N 87.2891°W / 31.99123 ; -87.2891 ( Wilcox County Courthouse Historic District )
Historic district , centered on the Wilcox County Courthouse , that features a wide variety of 19th and early 20th century architectural styles
Greek Revival style school building , built 1845 to 1850 as a boarding school for girls
intro: This is a list of the National Register of Historic Places listings in Wilcox County, Alabama. This is intended to be a complete list of the properties and districts on the National Register of Historic Places in Wilcox County, Alabama, United States. Latitude and longitude coordinates are provided for many National Register properties and districts; these locations may be seen together in a Google map. There are 15 properties and districts listed on the National Register in the county.
